bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, September 5, 1950

div1.p: Hench requests that Siler keep Hench's letters regarding Kean's medical treatment confidential.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, September 5, 1950
div1.opener:
September 5, 1950
Colonel J. F. Siler
Gorgas Memorial Institute
1835 Eye Street, N. W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
I was greatly concerned when I got word of General Kean's illness.
I received yesterday also a letter from his son, Robert. Last Saturday I
wrote you the enclosed note and having done so, got in touch with one of
our urologists. He agreed with me that the punch operation was a much
simpler and safer procedure than a prostateciomy in any event, but certainly
in a man of 90. However, as we talked it over frankly, the thought occurred
to me that my worry might be stimulating me to meddlesome interference and
therefore I did not mail the letter.

All day Sunday I kept trying to think what I could do ethically
but decided that long distance advice would be misplaced. In view of the
fact that General Kean could not even stand a simple cystostomy, it is
probable that he would have reacted with equal seriousness to the punch
operation. Please, therefore, consider these two letters confidential and
a matter just between ourselves.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
